main_point: The professor explains B-tree indexing and query planning and how to interpret evidence when measurements can be misleading.
detail1: The professor distinguishes mutex (a process) from latency (a proxy/measurement).
detail2: He suggests testing an asymmetric prediction involving hash collision and deadlock.
attitude: Casual but analytical; he warns against over-trusting a neat correlation.
organization_point: He adds a tangent about a funding detail to show real-world constraints.
connecting_point: The example about controlling for entropy shows how bias can flip an apparent pattern.
